title: Justice and Kingship
shortSummary: Deuteronomy 17 provides instructions for maintaining holiness and justice within Israel, including laws against idolatry and guidelines for judicial decisions. It also outlines the qualifications and responsibilities of a king, emphasizing obedience to God's law and humility in leadership.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - Israel's wilderness period before entering the Promised Land

keyCharacters.name: Priests and Levites
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders responsible for teaching the law and administering justice in difficult cases.

keyCharacters.name: Judge
keyCharacters.description: Appointed official who works with priests to render decisions in complex legal matters.

keyCharacters.name: King
keyCharacters.description: Future ruler of Israel chosen by God from among the Israelites, tasked with leading according to God's statutes.

definitions.definition: A physical defect or imperfection that disqualifies an animal from being offered as a sacrifice.
Something detestable or loathsome to God, especially idolatry or disobedience.
Acting arrogantly or willfully in disobedience to God's appointed authorities.
The celestial bodies such as the sun, moon, and stars, which some nations worshipped as gods.

outline.heading: Prohibition of Defective Sacrifices
outline.description: God forbids offering animals with blemishes as sacrifices, emphasizing the need for purity and reverence in worship.

outline.heading: Judgment for Idolatry
outline.description: Instructions for identifying and punishing those who worship other gods, including the requirement of multiple witnesses and the method of execution by stoning.

outline.heading: Appeal to Priests and Judges
outline.description: Guidance for resolving difficult legal cases by consulting the priests, Levites, and judges at the place God chooses, with strict adherence to their rulings.

outline.heading: Establishment of a King
outline.description: Regulations for Israel’s future monarchy, including the king’s selection, restrictions on horses, wives, and wealth, and the requirement to study God’s law to lead humbly and faithfully.

application: Obey God's commands fully, avoiding any compromise in worship or moral conduct.
Respect and submit to godly authority and judicial decisions as a reflection of obedience to God.
Leaders should remain humble, continually study Scripture, and avoid accumulating power or wealth that could lead them away from God.
Seek God’s guidance in difficult decisions through prayer and consultation with mature believers.

keyVerses.text: At the mouth of two witnesses, or three witnesses, shall he that is worthy of death be put to death; but at the mouth of one witness he shall not be put to death.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the importance of fair and just legal procedures to prevent wrongful punishment.

keyVerses.text: Thou shalt in any wise set him king over thee, whom the LORD thy God shall choose: one from among thy brethren shalt thou set king over thee: thou mayest not set a stranger over thee, which is not thy brother.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights God's sovereign role in appointing leaders and the importance of choosing a king from among God's people.

keyVerses.text: And it shall be, when he sitteth upon the throne of his kingdom, that he shall write him a copy of this law in a book out of that which is before the priests the Levites: And it shall be with him, and he shall read therein all the days of his life: that he may learn to fear the LORD his God, to keep all the words of this law and these statutes, to do them:
keyVerses.significance: These verses emphasize the necessity for leaders to be grounded in Scripture and to govern according to God's Word.
